Once, a long time ago, I cut myself.  For a week or so, I cut open my left arm, either in the middle of the forearm, or along three parts of my shoulder, all on the left arm.  I don't know why I did it.  I know I got the idea from someone who my first girlfriend had done some questionable (in a sexual manner) things with.  He told me about the whole "real life" vampire idea, ie people who drank either their own blood or another's.  Somehow, this led to me cutting myself, ostensibly to taste my own blood (I believe the standard description of blood's taste like that of copper).  Now, I need to say this wasn't anything "serious".  It left a slight mark, and the skin swelled up, but I really only cut until there was a decent amount of blood welling up in the cut...not even enough that it would drip down.  Then, to keep the image alive, I'd suck it a little, to get some taste of it.

But I really don't know if that was my real motivation for it.  To this day, it is something I really can not explain to myself...it goes against human nature, and I remember I found it very difficult to do.  So...if it was so hard, why did I do it?  My girlfriend didn't like it either, which just adds another incentive not to do it.  Admittedly, she didn't actually tell me to stop, she just said she didn't like it.

I also remember once trying to tell someone about it...I tried to make the cut on my forearm obvious, but when he didn't notice it, I brought it up, and ultimately said something along the lines of "I cut myself" and showed the cut to him.  He just kind of shrugged it off with an "oh".  I'll admit, he could have easily dismissed as something accidental, since it really didn't look like much more than a scratch.  No matter, I guess.  Just as I didn't really know why I cut myself, I also wasn't entirely sure why I wanted him to know.  He wasn't even my closest friend to begin with...more like someone I carpooled with.  Maybe I just thought someone should know, since it's really a rather bad thing to be doing to one's self.  Maybe I just wanted someone to say "don't do that".  Maybe I just wanted to relate to the person my girlfriend fooled around with.  I don't know.

To this day, four years later, I still don't.

Someone recently told me they absolutely hate when people begin papers with a definition.  So, in honor of that person, I begin:

According to Wikipedia, Polyamory is the desire, practice, or acceptance of having more than one loving, intimate relationship at a time with the full knowledge and consent of everyone involved.  It is similar to Polygamy, although I believe polygamy tends to be a more rigid system, and is perhaps more applicable to marriage.  Regardless, the concept of "multiple" relationships is something I've never really given much thought to.

Naturally, I have encountered the concept before in the past, but since I never really imagined it could apply to me, I didn't really give much thought.  Polygamy was something that happened in other religions, but since I was all Catholic (and, regardless of my current religious affiliation, would probably have a Christian wedding), it was something that happened to other people.  Then there's also the concept of "open" relationships.  Although essentially neutral about, there was something somehow did not sit well with me.  As I understood it, open relationships were for "swingers", once again something I never viewed myself as being.  If others want it, by all means, have and enjoy...but it didn't really seem appropriate for me.

So, polyamory.  Multiple, intimate relationships.  How's that not an open relationship.  Well, I think a key part of it is the INTIMATE thing.  It implies a genuine, emotional attachment.  Swinging is the exact opposite...fooling around with whatever happens to come your way.  In my mind, a truly polyamorous relationship leaves no room for one night stands, bar pick-ups, what have you.

Another question...can it work?  I guess to answer that, you first have to decide...does love (read: an emotional, romantic relationship) necessitate singular devotion to one person?  Is it truly an all or nothing deal, where, in falling in love with a person, all of your "romantic resources" are transferred to that one person?  A difficult question.  Well, chew on this.  When you break up with someone, do you stop loving them?  Indeed, even after moving on and starting anew, doesn't SOME feeling still remain for your past loves?  To this day, I know I still have a blind spot for my first girlfriend, and there are times where I might still pine for her, wish I could be with her again.  If it is possible to be in a truly loving relationship with one person, while still maintaining a lingering sense of attachment to an ex, perhaps that means love doesn't have to be monogamous...maybe it can be shared.  

Imagine...people complain about how complex monogamous relationships are, how difficult it must be to work out an arrangement with three, or even more people!  I've always felt the most important quality in a relationship (of any sort really) is a capacity for communication.  Naturally, the only way for communication to foster, there also needs to be a very strong, mutual, sense of respect and trust (and probably a bit of patience) fostered.  The potential for deceit, coercion, even infidelity (and it is definitely possible in a polyamorous relationship) are magnified tremendously, and the only way the inevitable pitfalls can be worked out is through honest communication, and the commitment to work through them.

Clearly, there need to be strong guidelines worked out, and I would feel they should be clearly outlined and discussed by all members of the relationship to work...and all should abide by them.  Naturally, just what these rules are will depend on the people.  I don't think I could honestly handle an open relationship, and don't feel there is room for haphazard "sleeping around" for any relationship I am a part of.  However...if another member truly has some attraction/attachment to a person they've known, and I am aware of this before any fooling around has happened, I think I could bring myself to accept this.  Indeed, I also think I would rather enjoy that type of freedom myself.

Which brings me to another aspect...the possible benefits of polyamory.  First and foremost (and I do believe this is more important), there are more than just the two people in the relationship.  When there are disputes between members (as there inevitably will be), the third person can act as a mediator of sorts, acting as a sympathetic ear for both parties, and hopefully helping to diffuse and help heal the situation.  Naturally, there is also the benefit of having a little "variety" in a relationship, since the relationship doesn't need to come to an end solely because there is an attraction to another person (we are still animals, to a degree).  There are also economic and familial advantages, but I won't delve into them at the moment, since I'm a bit young and don't really desire to consider that stage of my life quite yet.

Naturally, there are also some rather compelling issues that might arise.  The first, and most obvious, is the issue of jealousy.  Not everyone is capable of sharing their loved one, and this is something that needs to be worked out immediately, if the relationship is to continue in a healthy manner.  I feel that this is where the trust and communication issues come most strongly into play.  Adding another person into the mix needs to be decided carefully, and all members of the group should have equal say in the decision.  In that absence of that, it becomes far too easy for cheating...fooling around with someone without the knowledge of the members of the group.  In fact, I would say this can be even more detrimental in a polyamorous relationship...a whole group can be broken up if that is trust is compromised, and since it is so essential, that trust can be far far harder to get back once it's lost.  I'll also just mention in passing, for your own consideration, the difficulty members of a polyamorous relationship must have with making the nature of their relationship known to a rather close-minded world.

Alright, I'd say I'm pretty done for now.  I would just like to close by mentioning that I wrote this up really only considering a relationship which is completely balanced in nature...there can also be so called "V" relationships, where there is a single person who has two partners that aren't involved with each other on quite as deep a level as the center connector (if they were, that could be a triangle relationship), as well as there being a central "primary" relationship, with satellite "secondary" relationships only fulfilling certain needs (be they solely emotional, sexual, or what have you), in addition to many others.

All in all, it makes for some pretty interesting reading.  I definitely recommend checking out the wiki article on it: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polyamory  If for no other reason, it is interesting to consider another, radically different, approach to something that has a rather standardized (and perhaps flawed, or at least incomplete, given divorce rates nowadays) preconception in our society.

So, I've been thinking about updating this thing for something like a week now, but I've just not actually sat down to do it.  Admittedly, this is partly due to a lack of inspiration (though I've no shortage of material...).  Regardless, I've decided to just sit down and, inspiration or not, start typing.  Forgive any stream of conscious writing that may ensue, I assure, 'tis not intentional.

Right, so, for those who don't know, I don't live in Saugus anymore.  If you're reading this, you should know that already, but just in case, there it is.  I'm not in Allston, living in an apartment with this cool cat I met from New England Institute of Art.  He's an animation student, fellow Capoerista (moreso than me, as of late, frustrating as that may be), fellow philosophizer, and all-around good guy.

I must say, although I may have moved out rather abruptly (and perhaps a bit early, in retrospect), I am eternally glad that I did so.  Since moving (and especially thanks to who I moved with), I have met some very cool people who I do believe are beginning to fill some voids I've had for awhile.

Chronologically, the first of these new additions was a character we shall refer to as Angel.  I can confidently say he is nothing like any other friend I've ever had.  Big hair, womanizer, gangsta, playa, partier, listener of rap...these things all apply to Angel.  Not exactly standard friend material for me.  Nonetheless, we seemed to hit it off, and for a good 1.5 to 2 months, I saw the kid essentially daily.  It was quite an experience.  To say there was a generous amount of alcohol imbibed is an understatement.  All in all, it was a fairly good time.

However, there was recently...an event that occurred.  It involved much alcohol, keys being borrowed, and stormy emotions.  The long and the short of it is I've come the closest I've ever been to an all out fight with someone, and it was a bit of an eye-opener in some ways.  First off, I've never imagined that I'd find myself in a situation that could cause ME to escalate a situation to a physical confrontation, so that was strange.  It also made me rethink how freely I trust people, since the situation came about due to how freely I trust people.  Nonetheless, the situation did ultimately end with no one being hurt (physically) and a status quo of sorts being restored.  Nonetheless, my friendship with Angel, while not being put to an end, has certainly been changed.  *shrugs*  It was a learning experience.

Next up: Pete and Pete (not their real names, but whatev).  Although I did, technically, meet them before Angel, I don't think I started really getting to know them until after Angel, so they come second.  They are congenital (though not identical) twins, and they're honestly the shit, near as I can tell.  One, Peta (think Peter with a Bostonian accent) is all about plants and whatnot.   At first glance, I definitely connected more with him than his brother (we'll say Peter).  I think this is because he seems to be, like me, quieter and more introspective.  We've had many cool and interesting conversations, and I definitely like the guy.  My one complaint is it seems to be mildly difficult to get him away from his girlfriend/partner/girl interest/wtf ever.

However, the marauding girl left the stage clear for me to get to know his brother, Peter.  Now, this is a cool guy.  Far more energetic and out going than his brother, Peter nonetheless has a deep side that I actually find I identify even more with than Peta.  Truly, the more I get to know him, the more I value his friendship and, in truth, prefer it over Peta's (although they're really both awesome, so it's a moot point, especially given their brotherly, nigh constant, togetherness).  Regardless, we seem to be growing ever closer, and I'm thankful for that.

And now, the most recent addition to my social circle...a girl I met through my roommate.  I'm not even sure what to call her, so I won't.  Regardless, her entrance to my life definitely turned things upside down.  Out of the blue, I started feeling emotions I've literally not felt in years.  For once, I find myself actually WANTING to worry about another.  I freely acknowledge that there is probably much pain that can arise from pursuing a serious relationship of any sort with her, yet I don't care.  If anything, that makes me want to be with her all the more.  Even more amazing?  She seems to return the feelings.

So, what's the catch?  The catch, dear readers, is she's with my roommate.
And that's something I feel I need to leave for another entry, for there are many thoughts I've had with that.  Know that, for now, I've secured his blessing (as best I can anyway, given the situation), and have opted to see where this twisty, but infinitely interesting, road will take me.


And I'm never looking back.

So, this morning I got home from a party that concluded one of the single best weeks of my life.  I had my Bautizado yesterday, which is a big festival we have once a year in Capoeira.  It was my group's first Bautizado on our own, and it was truly incredible.  Our mestre, Cabeca, came over from Brazil, and we had high level cords from New York and California over with their students.  We had an entire week of workshops, two presentations, and I moved up a rank...I'm now a full-fledged yellow cord ^_^

Then we had the party last night, which was just amazing.  I never realized I could have such a good time at a party, but it makes a huge difference when you actually know everyone their, and literally everyone's good friends.  We were all hanging out together, joking around, Cabeca gave this really awesome thank-you speech, we all clapped and cheered for him, Italo, and ourselves.

The whole week, I've been either sleeping or doing Capoeira.  I've had virtually no free time.  I'm on the verge of being broke.  And I'm completely happy and, above all, satisfied.

Ayudame o Berimbau.  Ayudame a Cantar.
Help me Berimbau...help me to sing.

Take care all.

So, in an unprecedented turn of events, I'm actually posting twice within a month of each other.  Kinda weird.

In either case, it's important to note that I'm feeling way better than last time.  I know I got Frank and Vo, and although it's true Fred's leaving, I don't actually know that that's necessarily a terrible thing.

I'm really unhappy about how school went this semester, and I think part of why it went so bad was Fred.  No offence to him, but it's hard to give a damn and try when the person who's in all the same classes as you (and also happens to be your friend) doesn't care, doesn't do his work, and does better than you.  *shrugs* Who knows?  Suffice to say I'm far more confident about my future, both academically and otherwise, than I was just a week or so ago.

Maybe it's the weather.

Hmm...so, I guess I'm going to take a stab at writing something meaningful about my life in this old journal of mine.  It's been so long, I'm kinda out of practice. Ah well, here goes.

I've been worried lately.  Not the stomach clenching, paralyzing worry of looming disaster, but the more the quiet, passive worry of trouble, quite literally, on the horizon.  The antithesis of the so-called "light at the end of the tunnel".  It's a long way off, but it's coming inexorably closer, and I've yet to see how it can be stopped.

And as problems tend to be, I'm not sure how much of a problem this will really pan out to be.  I'm confident I'll make it through alright, but I'm not looking forward to it.

This perceived problem is my fall semester.  Through three very different courses of events coming together at once, it seems that the three closest people in my life will be, by and large, separated from me.  Vo's planning to move off to Umass Lowell, Frank's returning to school (which, in addition to his full-time job, will essentially bring his availability for chillage to zero) and Fred's planning on taking off with his friend for the semester.

Now, these aren't exactly insurmountable odds, clearly.  While it is true Vo will be far away, he does make the trip up to campus on a regular basis already, it'll just have to be reversed.  However, it'll make the spontaneous visits that are our typical strategies for hanging out less than feasible at the least, all but impossible at the worst.  Especially if he continues to have classes late as he does now, which I do fully expect him to.

Then there's Fred...his departure was the one I learned of first, and it's probably the one that worries me the most.  Whereas Vo will at least still be within driving distance, Fred plans to leave altogether.  He and his friend will be traveling constantly, and probably will be mainly more towards the Florida region.  He won't really be all that accessible.  The fact is, Fred filled a huge void within me that was left gaping when Ross died.  While it's true, he didn't fit the gap just right (think a circle small enough to fit in a square hole) he showed up in a point when I was missing something.  He's the asshole gamer that I can joke around with virtually constantly.  I can say anything to him, with no fear of offending, and he to me.  We compliment each other in public places so well that other people are attracted to our incessant chatter...perhaps solely because of the audacity of what we say sometimes.

Of course, the sad fact is, he's not Ross.  Even sadder, I know he has the exact type of relationship I had with Ross with his own friend (less than surprising) and the two compliment each other far better than I do with him, just like he and I don't match as I did with Ross.  But it's something, and now it looks like he's leaving.  The hole's coming back, and it just might be worse this time.
You see, Fred's also sort of become synonymous with my career at NEiA...he was there literally from day one, we've shared almost all our classes, and I've probably learned more from him about web/graphic design than from all of my other classes combined.  In many ways, he's (most likely unknowingly) been a support keeping me going.  And he's my only friend at my school.  Yes, there's Tristan, but (and no offense to him) he's just not that close, and there's just not the potential for a friendship with him that's on a level even close to Vo or Fred.

I don't mean to belittle my friendship with Vo or Frank by carrying on so much about Fred...perhaps it's the fact that I seriously can believe I won't see him again after this summer semester, whereas I know, beyond any shadow of a doubt, that I'll keep in touch with Vo, and we'll still keep close.  That support, thank the powers that be, has never really been threatened.

I'm just not sure what's going to happen.

I purchased the Starcraft Boardgame...it arrived yesterday.  In fact, it was sitting on my front porch when I woke up.  It was amazing.  I played a single round with Frank, and it made the rest of my night a far brighter time.



Salvation has come...and it is 180 brightly colored plastic figurines.

After Ross made a joke, referring to an earlier dream that night that he couldn't possibly have known, I get into the passenger seat of a car, he's the driver.

While we're driving...

Me: "Ross...are you a dream?"
Ross: (after thinking for a moment, responds in a completely serious voice)"Mmm...maybe."
Me: (Not satisfied, suspecting the truth, I sit, thinking, and don't respond.)
Ross: (after a few minutes, while I was thinking)"Dream truth? Yes."


Him admitting this was too much for me...I got so upset the dream rapidly faded, and I awoke.  I couldn't get back to sleep.

After all the attempts I've been making of having a lucid dream, and remembering/controlling my dreams, I finally become aware, and lose it in one of the situations I most wanted to hang on to.

Why is the only dream I have of Ross so fleeting?  Those few moments with him were so great, even if he was "only" a dream.

I miss you, buddy.

So...here I am.  My good friend, Ross, has died.  The day of my birthday...the day that marked the end of my teenage years, also marked the end of the life of the friend I was supposed to carry with me into retirement.  We were supposed to open a bar in Switzerland.  We were supposed to visit Europe.  I was going to show him Capoeira, he was going to show me his breakdancing moves.

Who will I tell all my random thoughts, worries and wishes?  Who will I send the random websites I stumbled upon?  Who do I turn to for computer help?

Who else knew what SOMFASAP meant, and honestly thought it was funny?  Who else could I trade 'your mom' jokes with, and honestly, somehow, make it work?  Whose house will I drive/walk/run to in the middle of a summer night, simply because I was bored and wanted to go for a drive down Route One?

Who will force me to branch out, and use new fangled services like Ebay and Paypal?  Who will send me funny websites?

Who did I KNOW, beyond any shadow of a doubt, would always be there.  Who else always, no matter what else in my life occurred, was still online, just a single IM away?  Who did I never lose touch with, never fight with and always trust?  Who understood me, and grew up with me as I entered, and finally, left, those turbulent teenage years?

Who heard my cries against my parents, school, life, and everything else that threatened to close in on me, always, and somehow kept on pulling through for and with me, for ten years?


You Ross.  You did.  And now you're gone.  I miss you so goddamn much.

<3 u, Rossmo, Kazin Kilu, nigface, Un Jouet Casse.

I love you, my friend.

So...I'm 20?

Yeah, seems so.  I'm not a teenager anymore.  I suppose this is the time to cease my life by the horns, take hold of the reigns, turn the key, take the plunge, etc etc.

All because I'm a day older?

By what may be considered a strange coincidence I finished reading a book today (ie, the 15th) called "The Science of Changing your Mind".  I don't need to tell you what it's about.  But I will...it's about breaking out of habits.  Breaking free of your emotions, and taking charge of your life.

The biggest secret?  Don't be afraid of novel experiences.  In other words...not only should you not fear change...you should embrace it.

Interesting that I'd finish a book about change on my last day as a teenager.

Just to add to that, I also finished it on the day I gave my job notice that I'm leaving.  I won't get into my reasons, the list's too long.  Suffice to say, I want a change, and going to school is a perfect time to do so.

I dunno.  The pieces are in place.  Now, do I make the right moves?  Do I win the game?

We'll see! ;-)

I just finished up my first Capoeira class tonight.  Wow, I have to say, it was great.  I'm all sore, pretty tired, and I've identified one definite blister, with two possibles on the same foot...and yet, I feel excellent.  It was a really good workout, it was damned satisfying, and I have to say, it was actually very fun.

So, now I do Tai Chi and Capoeira, each once a week.  I think I'll kick off each day to some push ups/sit ups, followed by stretching and Capoeira, then I'll finish off each night with stretching and Tai Chi.  That way I'll get woken up nice and quick in the morning with a healthy aerobic exercise, then I can finish up at the end of the day with nice, relaxing, centering Tai Chi.

And now, to ponder the big question of the day...do I drop the 3 grand to replace the engine in my car, or just buy a new one :-/

Anyway, I'm off for the night.

Laters

Something...unsettling has been happening to me lately.  Well, I think it should be unsettling, but it's not.  No, if anything, I kind of like it, but more in the way that it's strange and different...something to think about/distract myself.  It seems like my life is becoming more and more surreal, dreamlike.  In particular, my dreams have been bleeding more and more into my real life.  There have been a number a times, not many, but quite a bit considering, when I literally thought something happened, only to later discover it was merely a dream...entire conversations, things happening to my car, etc etc.  And there are times, during the day, when everything seems to get hazy, or...something.  I don't know, things just take on a certain unreal quality to them.

I wonder what causes this?  Will this keep happening, gradually becoming more and more common until my waking life becomes a dream?

Just a thought that was bouncing around in my head.

I feel rather helpless (don't we all?).

Well, I don't know how accurate that is. I just found a website...www.wefeelfine.org  It's a bunch of boucing circles in a window...each circle is a single sentence pulled from people's blogs.  This site grabs upwards of 10,000 sentences that start with the words "I feel" and put them into a window.  It touched me.

I've once again falled into the now familiar habit of waiting in anticipation...I'm just trying to live my life until college comes 'round, since I'm not getting the satisfaction I need/want from work, and I'm not really seeing people out of work overly often.  Admittedly, the past two days have been welcome exceptions to this, and I really hope I can get them to continue happening.

At work, I'm torn between a desire to "move up" and go work in places that are busier.  There would be an increase of stress, naturally, due to the higher number of people I'd have to serve.  Naturally, there would (hopefully) be a comparable monetary improvement as well.  I just don't know if I really want to deal with the added stress...the money really isn't much of an issue for me right now I guess.

Well, I've run out of things to write about off the top of my head.

Good day.

I remember a distance time, now far off in my past.  This was, in my memory, the first major turning point...the first, true, life-altering experience that ultimately defined who I am today.  I can honestly say that no one thing has affected my life to the magnitude of this event, even if  it was spread out over three summers.

I am, of course, speaking of scout camp.  It was during that time that I met James Galloway, my personally adopted mentor (although I'm not really sure if he even knows this...).  From the first day, when I worked as a 14 year old Assistant counselor, I can remember meeting him.  I had a 20 dollar bill, and I was asking around change.  I don't remember why, but I remember something about how he treated me, versus how everyone else approached me actually touched me.  He gave me some degree respect, and believe me, that's something I needed at that time.  Heh, he also gave me some other firsts, and he was my "gateway" into another world.

A year later, I returned to camp.  At his invite, I ventured down to the now-infamous Cabin 7...the "elite" cabin, the biggest one, complete with its own porch and relative isolation from all the other cabins...a haven, and ultimately probably one of my most comfortable homes, with the entire Onway Forest as my backyard.  In Cabin 7, I took essentially an entire summer's worth (7.5 weeks, to be exact) of punishment...admittedly good-natured, but still, it was verbal harrasment.  To a level I'd never experienced before.  Odd as this may sound, it changed me for the better.  I feel that I grew, became stronger, more secure in myself.  This security...this confidence, would only continue to grow as years passed, but this summer began it.

Naturally, throughout this whole time, I also talked to James.  We philosophized, observed, talked...I learned.  The depth I have, though I feel has always been there, was developed by those talks.  Although there was a lot that was already there, I feel James helped to fully bring it about in me, or helped to unlock the potential.

But on top of all that, the times were wonderful.  There was a sense of carelessness, a sense of freedom I would never experience again, in any capacity.  For the brief time when I lived in those cabins, my life was a collection of trees, my friends, and the campfires.

No worries...truly, I had no worries.  I could forget about my parents, and the looming unhappiness I'd undoubtedly face when I went home every weekend.  There was always the promising allure of Camp Onway...a place where I could be who I wanted (and believe me, I was, for once, completely content with who I was), and I could do what I wanted.  It wasn't a major hassle to work with the scouts, and when I wasn't babysitting boy scouts, I was doing what I wished.

I guess what I'm trying to say is...I was happy there.  And I sort of want those times back.

People, we have reached college.  We are officially adults, college students.  None of us may really have an idea of what the real world will bring, but we are nevertheless expected to be wiser people than we were in high school.  We're expected to have grown out of the petty rivalries, have gained the ability to shrug things off.  At this point in our lives, we should have developed the ability to think before we act, control our emotions, and act irrationally.

Apparently, this is far too much to ask of some people.

Apparently, we have not grown up.

That is not the case.  I'll admit, your actions are what pushed me far enough to write this entry, but this is honestly is quite general.

It is caused by people over reacting, not thinking their actions and words through, and being unwilling to communicate.  It is caused by stupid decisions, and it is caused by people allowing themselves to be controlled and influenced by others.

Drama should be basically gone by our college years.

The other thing I've noticed is an unwillingness to take actions to remove one's self from an unfavorable situation.  Although I've noticed this far less, and it's really not "as" immature as drama can be, it is still something I have noticed amongst people.  I don't understand it.

Oh well.

I live without regrets.  I'm fully aware of my words, and I'm fully aware of what they mean.  And I'm not taking any of it back.
